1.text: Canst thou draw out leviathan with a hook? or his tongue with a cord which thou lettest down?

2.text: Canst thou put a hook into his nose? or bore his jaw through with a thorn?

3.text: Will he make many supplications to thee? will he speak soft words to thee?

4.text: Will he make a covenant with thee? wilt thou take him for a servant for ever?

5.text: Wilt thou play with him as with a bird? or wilt thou bind him for thy maidens?

6.text: Shall the companions make a banquet of him? shall they part him among the merchants.

7.text: Canst thou fill his skin with barbed irons? or his head with fish spears?

8.text: Lay thy hand upon him, remember the battle, do no more.

9.text: Behold, the hope of him is in vain: shall not one be cast down even at the sight of him?

10.text: None is so fierce that he dare rouse him: who then is able to stand before me?

11.text: Who hath first benefited me, that I should repay him? whatever is under the whole heaven is mine.

12.text: I will not conceal his parts, nor his power, nor his comely proportion.

13.text: Who can discover the face of his garment? or who can come to him with his double bridle?

14.text: Who can open the doors of his face? his teeth are terrible around.

15.text: His scales are his pride, shut together as with a close seal.

16.text: One is so near to another, that no air can come between them.

17.text: They are joined one to another, they stick together, that they cannot be sundered.

18.text: His sneezings flash light, and his eyes are like the eyelids of the morning.

19.text: Out of his mouth go burning lamps, and sparks of fire dart forth.

20.text: Out of his nostrils issueth smoke, as out of a seething pot or caldron.

21.text: His breath kindleth coals, and a flame issueth from his mouth.

22.text: In his neck remaineth strength, and sorrow is turned into joy before him.

23.text: The flakes of his flesh are joined together: they are firm in themselves; they cannot be moved.

24.text: His heart is as firm as a stone; yes, as hard as a piece of the nether millstone.

25.text: When he raiseth himself, the mighty are afraid: by reason of breakings they purify themselves.

26.text: The sword of him that attacketh him cannot hold: the spear, the dart, nor the habergeon.

27.text: He esteemeth iron as straw, and brass as rotten wood.

28.text: The arrow cannot make him flee: sling-stones are turned with him into stubble.

29.text: Darts are counted as stubble: he laugheth at the shaking of a spear.

30.text: Sharp stones are under him: he spreadeth sharp pointed things upon the mire.

31.text: He maketh the deep to boil like a pot: he maketh the sea like a pot of ointment.

32.text: He maketh a path to shine after him; one would think the deep to be hoary.

33.text: Upon earth there is not his like, who is made without fear.

34.text: He beholdeth all high things: he is a king over all the children of pride.
